vulnerability_information:
Hi Team,

This report is the pretty much same of my closed report here: #223355 , the difference is __[BUG#2] when a user created an account BUT did not supply the password__, therefor there is nothing to reauthenticate when deleting the account, it will successfully delete the account without supplying password because the user not yet set his/her password.

The removal of account is one of the sensitive part of a web application that needs to protect, therefor removing an account should validate the authenticity of the legitimate user.

  1. The user create a weblate account to a shared computer (office, library, cafe)
  2. The user not yet set his/her password
  3. Left the account open.
  4. Intruder came and try to delete the users account
  5. Intruder can easily delete the account because the system did not protect it by asking the password to validate that the person deleting the account is the legitimate user.

### Mitigation:

I am not sure how you are going to handle this one, because reauthentication is the solution for this, but since the user not yet set his/her password, reauthentication will not work and the account can delete successfully, please consider my suggestion below.

### Suggestion to mitigate this:

The password creation should be enforced on the registration form, that will resolved many issues regarding the login and password reset mentioned on my other report here: #229528

When the user already have password on account registration, you don't have to touch the code of the account deletion form, you can leave it as it is since the user already have password to reauthenticate.

Let me know if you need more information or if there is anything i can help with.

Regards
Japz
title: Insecure Account Removal #2

activities.message:
I have another idea to mitigate this :) , please see below suggestion.

When the user account not yet set his/her password and click the delete account button, __do not allow the deletion of the account__, prompt a message saying that incomplete account setup cannot be deleted, please contact weblate support.

You have to return an ambiguous message :) , so that when intruder tries to delete the account, he does not have any idea what is wrong, if the legitimate user encounter this, for sure the user will contact weblate support, with that being said, the account is safe and you can assure the authenticity of the person who is deleting the account.

Hope you consider my suggestion if you are not going to change the registration form, because this is the easiest way to mitigate this :)

Regards
Japz

When the user account not yet set his/her password and click the delete account button, do not allow the deletion of the account, prompt a message saying that incomplete account setup cannot be deleted, please contact weblate support.

You have to return an ambiguous message :) , so that when intruder tries to delete the account, he does not have any idea what is wrong, if the legitimate user encounter this, for sure the user will contact weblate support, with that being said, the account is safe and you can assure the authenticity of the person who is deleting the account.

Hope you consider my suggestion if you are not going to change the registration form, because this is the easiest way to mitigate this :)

Regards
Japz

activities.message: Well there is also another problem with the reauthentication - most people do not register with login/password, but by using third party service. Reauthentication makes no sense there as the service will in most cases automatically login user. So indeed users without password set are not protected here, but I'm not sure we can do better here. With your proposed solution we end up handling most of account deletions through support, what is also something I'd like to avoid.
activities.markdown_message: Well there is also another problem with the reauthentication - most people do not register with login/password, but by using third party service. Reauthentication makes no sense there as the service will in most cases automatically login user. So indeed users without password set are not protected here, but I'm not sure we can do better here. With your proposed solution we end up handling most of account deletions through support, what is also something I'd like to avoid.

activities.message:
Hi @nijel ,

>With your proposed solution we end up handling most of account deletions through support, what is also something I'd like to avoid.

Agreed, it's a bit hustle for the team that the deletion of account will fall through support.

I have an idea, my suggestion is the same __BUT__ this time we will remove the "please contact weblate support." and we will create a good ambiguous system message that will make the intruder confused. Please see below suggestion fix.

### Suggestion for fix.

__Suggested System Message:__ `Deletion of account requires password, please check your account.` , please observed that we removed that contact support part.

Now, when the user account don't have the password yet and the delete account button was clicked, below will be helpful sample scenario:

__INTRUDER:__ When the intruder click the delete button, __do not delete the account__, show the ambiguous message, the intruder will think that he needs to put a password because of the part of message `Deletion of account requires password`, but in reality there is not password set to the account yet, so intruder will end up bruteforcing the password (which rate limiting is in place) and can never get the correct password because there is no password yet :)

__LEGITIMATE USER:__ When the legitimate user click the delete button, __do not delete the account__, show the ambiguous message, when the user see the message, he will not confused because he knows that he didn't yet set the password of the account, therefor the user will enforce to create the password before he can delete the account and that would be much safe.

In this situation, you will see the importance of the `ambiguous message` , it will really help on this matter.

### Summary of the above scenarios:

When the user account don't have a password yet, do not allow to delete the account until they set the password.

Let me know if this make sense :)

Cheers
Japz

activities.message: Interesting approach, however I'm a bit worried how this approach survives localization of the error message. But it's probably worth trying.
activities.markdown_message: Interesting approach, however I'm a bit worried how this approach survives localization of the error message. But it's probably worth trying.

activities.message:
In the end this will not really help much, because we ask user to set password one he opens the profile, so the attacker will quite easily figure this out.

I will probably rather add email confirmation to the removal...

activities.message:
@nijel

>In the end this will not really help much, because we ask user to set password one he opens the profile, so the attacker will quite easily figure this out.

This will fall under my other report :) a bit related here: #229528

>I will probably rather add email confirmation to the removal...

Great! , this one is good in the situation of deleting account that don't have password, an email confirmation can be great defense :) As i said mine was only a suggestion, you can go ahead for the email confirmation for permanent fix, that would address the issue :)

Regards
Japz
